description.narrative: THE BROADER OPPORTUNITY The economic agenda is shifting rapidly and many are questioning the ability of the shareholder capitalism model to deliver fair and sustainable outcomes. Even institutions and thought -leaders, such as the WEF and the magazine the Economist, are even questioning whether we need to rethink the dominant structures of companies so the economy incentivises decisions leading to sustainable and fairer outcomes. The global narrative is opening to allow questions to be asked around whether alternative business structures, such as employee -ownership, co -operatives, benefit corporations and social enterprises (among others) hold answers to promoting a new breed of companies with sustainability and fairness instilled in their DNA. IN NATIONAL INFLUENCING In countries Oxfam works in, opportunities are opening for Oxfam and allies to be more propositional about the kinds of business structures that are better for people and planet – and the kind of policies that can help these structures enter the mainstream of the economy. Oxfam is well placed to be a thought -leader on this, due to its extensive experience in enterprise development of similar progressive models of business. As countries look to link programmes and influencing, promoting public policies that favour the kinds of companies that are closer to Oxfam's values can be key. Knowing what these companies look like and the evidence of their positive impacts will help tremendously. This project will allow us to map out the range of corporate structures that exist around the world and pull together what is already known about their impacts. IN THE SHORT TERM It would serve an immediate need of allowing us to be more specific in papers, speeches and advocacy meetings about the kinds of corporate models that could be promoted.
